results.title: Martin Luther King: The Legacy
results.brief_description: An excellent documentary which not only looks at the life and work of Dr. Martin Luther King, but at how his dream for an integrated United States has been realised today. Interviews with participants of the Civil Rights Movement, friends and family of Dr. King and those who sought to destroy him such as the FBI. As well as fascinating archival footage, there is also an excellent soundtrack which features Afro-american music contemporary to the era.

results.title: Martin Luther
results.creator_credit: Cassian Harrison, Richard Bradley, Lion Television, Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
Born in Germany at the height of the Black Death, Martin Luther was raised in a Europe dominated spiritually, economically and politically by the Roman Catholic Church. This two part series, narrated by Liam Neeson, explores the life of this important revolutionary thinker. In episode one, “Driven To Defiance”, we are taken through Luther’s early childhood and years as a student where his deepening spiritual faith leads him to a vocation as a monk. But on making a pilgrimage to the Vatican in Rome, he discovers a corrupt and bloated Church and a degenerate and cynical priesthood. The experience leads him to the writing of the 95 Theses, a call to arms against religious corruption and a return to the gospels of Jesus Christ. Central to the theses is Luther’s attack on the Catholic Church’s selling of Indulgence which are meant to ensure a dying person’s passage to Heaven. In calling for a spiritual renewal of Christianity, Luther’s 95 Theses lay the foundations for Protestantism. In episode two, “The Reluctant Revolutionary”, the Catholic Church responds to Luther’s attacks by charging him with heresy. But a fortunate historic confluence - the invention of the printing press - allows for the first time the wide dissemination of Luther’s ideas and beliefs which find popular support all across Europe. Luther attacks the Church hierarchy at his trial and his protests leads to revolutionary upheaval across the continent. The episode examines both Luther’s radical impact but also his refusal to support the peasant revolutionaries inspired by his rhetoric. Luther can imagine a spiritual revolutionary order but not an economic revolution. His vehement and ruthless attacks against the poor, the peasantry and against the Jews will resonate in Protestantism through the ages and lead to a tension in the Christian faiths which will see Catholicism brave the Reformation and paradoxically regain strength in the modern world as the Christian Church for the poor and the oppressed. Whatever the contradictions of his faith and life, the religious revolution inspired by Luther is undoubtedly one of the greatest singular moments in European history.

results.title: Martin four
results.creator_credit: Ben Hackworth and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: Caught up in the claustrophobic world of his mother, who lives in a drunken haze of romantic memories of exotic places, an aimless young gay man tries to make a connection with love and life in the present. Cast includes Susan Lyons, Todd MacDonald, Suzi Dougherty and Suzy Cato.

results.title: Martin Creed [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “TheEYE”.
Part of a series of interview-based profiles of contemporary visual artists in Britain. Martin Creed is one of Britain’s most engaging contemporary artists. His self-effacing work reflects an anxiety to communicate in a world already full of too many things. A solo exhibition organised by Southampton City Art Gallery in 2000 provided the first opportunity to reflect on a wide range of Creed’s creations, produced over a decade, including sculpture, installations, interventions, statements and also musical compositions performed with his band owada. Much of this work is illustrated here. Creed discusses his uncertainties about making new works and his reluctance to name what he does as ‘art’. He also illustrates how simple, ordinary objects, seen in new ways, can suggest often complex and contradictory meanings.

results.title: Martin Chuzzlewit
results.creator_credit: Pedr James, Chris Parr, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description: Charles Dickens’ classic tale is brought to the screen with an excellent cast of Paul Scofield, John Mills, Pete Postlethwaite, Tom Wilkinson and Julia Sawalha. Martin Chuzzlewit is a very wealthy old man. Having disinherited his grandson Martin, he only trusts his companion, the orphan Mary Graham, employed on the understanding that she will get no money. With a fortune to grasp, Chuzzlewit’s family bring forth all their cunning, greed and selfishness. There is the snivelling hypocrite Pecksniff with his two daughters Mercy and Charity and the evil Jonas who will resort to murder to gain the money.

results.title: Martin Bartfeld and Bruce McGuinness filming A Time to Dream in Melbourne
results.brief_description: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. Activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).

results.title: Martin Arnold: cinemnesis
results.brief_description: Martin Arnold is a contemporary Austrian experimental filmmaker. His short films make use of familiar Hollywood footage put through an optical printer to create effects of jarring, twitching and rhythmic vision. The sequence is stoped and started over and over from one frame and incrementally moves slowly ahead in a jumping fashion. The effect is nervous and jumpy and allows the viewer to contemplate further in an abstract fashion the notion of film and the ideas of memory and machinery. The ideas of Freud along with other thinkers like Derrida have informed the filmmaker. Ideas about memory and what is etched into the brain being in fact a vision which is clear and yet highly effected by emotions, places and thoughts. Displacing and decontextualising recognisable found footage causes the stable and reassuring images to become mildly disturbing. The human condition becomes technical and the nature of film is altered as what we thought of as mundane and everyday is oddly out of context. These short films are interesting and at the same time cause a mild discomfort.

results.title: Martha Clarke: light and dark
results.brief_description: The film portrays an artist’s imaginative sources, and the processes through which she creates an evening of theatrical dance. The film departs from traditional dance films by looking behind the finished performance to its imaginative sources and the process by which the performance grows.
results.description: The film portrays an artist’s imaginative sources, and the processes through which she creates an evening of theatrical dance. results.title: Martha
results.creator_credit: Rainer Werner Fassbinder and Peter Marthesheimer
results.brief_description: After Martha Heyer’s tyrannical father dies suddenly during their holiday in Italy, she meets and is proposed to by engineer Helmut Salomon, who sweeps her off her feet with a disturbing mixture of romance and intimidation. After their marriage Helmut’s behaviour becomes increasingly oppressive and Martha’s ever more fearful and desperate to please, as the film builds to a truly horrific climax. Whether taken as a psychological horror movie or as the blackest of black comedies, this is undoubtedly the most extreme and alarming of all of Fassbinder’s visions of married life. In German with English subtitles.
